Actually, this conclusion is not valid. Why would ability to create black hair, ie having certain amount of melanin producing melanocytes meant that black is your basis, and that stripes in which there are no melanin are “added”. One could argue that the basis is without melanin, and that on certain spots you increase the production of melanin thus leading to black stripes formation. This answer in fact would be more logical, as stripes are usually on the sun-exposed sides whereas the belly is white. Nevertheless, this does not confirm whether black or white is the “base”. In order to answer such question, we would have to dig deeper into evolution of zebras, and establish what they looked like before stripes were developed.

From an equine background, skin is an important factor when debating the stripes of a zebra. Equines are not like people. A horse with white hair and grey/black skin is classified as a grey, even if their appearance is white. A horse with pink/pale skin is classified as a true white.  Due to zebras being in the same genus as horses you can conclude that because the zebras skin is dark, it is black with white stripes as it lacks the characteristics of a true white equine. Obviously it’s more complicated then that but skin will give you a good indication of the colour of the zebra.

y'all are misunderstanding the video. what he meant by "black with white stripes” is not artistically/geometrically speaking, as in the "stripes” he's referring to aren't called stripes because of their shape (which some of you are arguing about), but rather which one is more "natural”. as mentioned in the video, white hair is more dominant in zebras, which is why people might jump to the conclusion that zebras are white with black stripes, BUT he did also say that a zebra's default state is to create black hair making it the more "natural” color (as explained during the melanin part) therefore, in his explanation, zebras are BLACK WITH WHITE STRIPES.

Edit: I'm not saying this is the ONLY correct explanation, rather i was just enlightening everyone and trying to make them understand his point. because, obviously, this can be looked at in a geometric way wherein it could be considered a white animal with black stripes because the white fur isn't consistent with its shape

They're white with black stripes... It's like a cat or most other mammals that have stripes... When a cat has stripes they almost always originate from the back (turtle shells and some very specific tabbies this is not the case however they are the exception not the rule) and as it travels down to their belly they basically run out of "ink" to continue the stripes meaning that say if you had a black and white cat with stripes the White would be the default and the black would be the ink and so the stripes would be black stopping before the belly... This is how coloration is determined from most mammals and also why you get a lot of pets with "socks" (aka a lack of coloration on their paws) and why animals who do have these socks almost always have the same lack of pigment on their bellies basically the printer had more ink then the one that with stripes.

There's another explanation to that. Delve into equine color genetics, and you will find that zebras are EE AA DD, so dominant bay dun. The striping is caused by dun, a modifier gene that also creates a striping pattern to a less extreme extent in horses. When you crossbreed a zebra to a horse, the zorse foal looks like an extreme version of a bay dun horse. All zorses born have an E_ A_ D_ base at minimum, meaning that all of them are genetically bay dun even if there are other color genes at play that may dilute the color or cover it, such as tobiano or cream. If you compare a zorse with a normal bay dun horse, you'll notice that the striping congregates in all of the same places. Dun is a primitive modifier gene that exists in all equids and partially evolved out of horses, which is why not all of them have it.
With this knowledge in mind, you can definitively say that zebras are bay (or black, as most would say) with dun (white) striping. Black with white stripes.

And yes black pigmentation of fur or skin is determined by melanin which is a protein so it's obviously coded for by a gene and expressed when the gene is activated or "turned on". In eukaryotes "off" is the default, genes get turned "on" as needed usually as a cell differentiates and they are activated. So the striping pattern is dictated by how the genes of the cells are activated, i.e. they are white with black stripes.

The proper way of describing a horse's coat is based on what you see - in the horse's physical description for, say, the veterinarian's knowledge, you're supposed to use the main color (which there is more of) and then marking shapes and colors (which there are less of). In horses where the ratio is more fifty-fifty, the descriptions either have the main coat color be both, or the one that visually "seems" to be more of.
If we treat zebras as horses, as they often are for veterinary descriptions, then the proper way of describing - at least most of them - is white with black stripes.
